step1.ptxt: Faults and Symptoms of Common Rail Diesel Components

entry.ptxt: Turbocharger sub-assembly malfunction (compressor side seal ring, turbine side seal ring, shaft, oil drain)
Difficult to start, rough idle, knocking, white smoke (when cold)

item.ptxt: Measure the resistance of the glow plug
Check the glow plug indicator light
When cranking during the "Check the Cylinder Compression" Active Test, if there is a high speed cylinder (approx. 100 rpm more than the other cylinders) that cylinder may lose compression.
If Injection Feedback Val #1 to #4 is more than 3 mm3/st, the cylinder may have a fault.

entry.ptxt: Rough idle, lack of power, black smoke, white smoke, knocking

item.ptxt: When an Injector Feedback Val is more than 3 mm3/st, there may be a malfunction in the corresponding cylinder. Injection Feedback Val #1 to #8 can be read after idling for 1 minute with the engine warmed up (the engine coolant temperature is higher than 75°C (167°F)).

atten4.ptxt: When the sliding resistance of the internal parts of the injector assemblies (nozzle needle, control valve) has increased due to internal contamination, injection quantity will increase at high common rail pressure due to a delay in fuel injector closure.

entry.ptxt: Circuit fault: The fuel injector does not open.
Difficult to start, rough idle, lack of power, black smoke, white smoke, knocking
When the injector driver has a fault, some DTCs may be stored.
Difficult to start, rough idle (especially when cold)

item.ptxt: Does not move smoothly
Does not close fully
Rough idling
EGR valve stuck closed: A loud turbocharger sound.

EGR valve stuck open: Difficult to start (does not stall), black smoke, white smoke (when engine is cold), lack of power, jerking (If there is an excess in the quantity of EGR and there is a heavy load, when the vehicle starts moving, a lack of power will be felt. Also, when racing the engine, there will be some black smoke).

entry.ptxt: Actual EGR Valve Pos, Target EGR Valve Pos

item.ptxt: Generally, Actual EGR Valve Pos = Target EGR Valve Pos +/-5% (fully closed: 0%, fully open: 100%).

Using the EGR valve Active Test, check whether Actual EGR Valve Pos follows Target EGR Valve Pos (the engine coolant temperature and intake air temperature should be considered when a malfunction occurs).
EGR valve is fully closed when the ignition switch is ON (engine stopped).
EGR valve opens to the halfway point at idling after the engine is warmed up.

When the EGR valve does not close, MAF (Mass Air Flow Sub-assembly) decreases when the vehicle is accelerated at full throttle. MAP also decreases in comparison to Target Booster Pressure, however there is not a large difference.
When leaving the vehicle idling, the normal range of EGR Close Lrn. Val. is 0 to 1 V.
In cases when EGR Close Lrn. Val. is out of the normal range (0 to 1 V), it is possible that the EGR valve cannot completely close.

atten3.ptxt: After replacing an fuel injector, the ECM requires registration (Click here ).

entry.ptxt: When the engine is misfiring, any fuel that has been injected but remains unburned is emitted as white smoke.
If oil leak occurs from turbine side seal, large amount of white smoke will be emitted from the exhaust pipe.
Internal oil leak is not visible from the outside of the turbocharger sub-assembly.

testgrp.testtitle: CONFIRM CONDITIONS PRESENT WHEN WHITE SMOKE APPEARED WITH CUSTOMER

test1.ptxt: Ask the customer about the conditions when the white smoke was emitted.
- What were the driving conditions when the white smoke was generated.
- Is the white smoke constantly emitted, or only occasionally?
- Does the white smoke occur only when the vehicle is cold, or when the vehicle is both cold and hot?
- Is the white smoke emitted just after starting the vehicle only, or does it continue while the vehicle is idling?
Determine the symptoms of the problem to narrow down the possible causes.

testgrp.testtitle: READ OUTPUT DTCS (RELATING TO ENGINE)

test1.ptxt: Connect the GTS to the DLC3.
Turn the ignition switch to ON and turn the GTS on.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Troubles.
Read pending DTCs.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Trouble Codes

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK WHEN WHITE SMOKE IS EMITTED

test1.ptxt: Start the engine.
Fully depress the accelerator pedal, and then release it.
Check whether white smoke is emitted or not when racing the engine.

atten3.ptxt: Be sure not to check for white smoke indoors.

item.ptxt: If the white smoke is emitted only just after engine start and disappears later, the smoke is not from the turbocharger.

If the turbocharger is the cause of the problem, regardless of whether the engine is cold or warmed up, there will be a large amount of white smoke to the extent that visibility is obstructed for a few meters in the area of the smoke (as shown in the illustration).

Depending on whether there is oil mixed with the fuel, or whether there is unburned fuel present, the smell of the exhaust gas differs. When oil is mixed in, the exhaust gas smells such as burning oil.

When continuously traveling with the engine close to idle for 1 hour or more, such as when in heavy traffic, unburned fuel accumulates in the catalytic converter, and can produce white smoke when accelerating.

entry.ptxt: White smoke is emitted just after engine start only
White smoke is always and continuously emitted
There is oil on the exhaust pipe, etc.

atten4.ptxt: The oil on the exhaust pipe may be from the transmission, etc.

item.ptxt: White smoke may be emitted at a specific exhaust gas temperature. Listed are possible symptoms and causes for this case. Use this information as reference when carrying out malfunction diagnosis.
The exhaust gas temperature may be checked using "Exhaust Temperature B1S2, Exhaust Temperature B1S3" in the Data List.

entry.ptxt: White smoke is emitted when the exhaust temperature is below 200°C (452°F) and the vehicle is traveling at low speed or when accelerating after decelerating.

item.ptxt: Related Data List
Exhaust Temperature B1S2
Exhaust Temperature B1S3

entry.ptxt: When continuously traveling with the engine close to idle for 1 hour or more, such as when in heavy traffic, unburned fuel accumulates in the catalytic converter, and can produce white smoke when accelerating*.

*: In this case the white smoke is not caused by a defect, so explain to the customer that the white smoke is caused by an accumulation of unburned fuel due to low-speed driving etc., and monitor the situation.

(If the customer reports that the problem only occurs after continuous driving in heavy traffic/low speed driving, the problem may resolve itself when the catalytic converter temperature is raised through high-speed driving. However, if the catalytic converter activity is reduced, this will not resolve the problem, so the catalytic converter must be replaced. Deterioration of the catalytic converter can cause an EGR malfunction and injector malfunction, so if there has not been any repair in the past, check and repair these components as well.)
White smoke is emitted when accelerating while the exhaust gas temperature is around 200 to 300°C (452 to 572°F) (in the process of rising to 500°C (932°F) for PM forced regeneration).

item.ptxt: Related Data List
Exhaust Temperature B1S2
Exhaust Temperature B1S3

Deterioration of the exhaust gas temperature sensor may be causing the sensor to read lower than the actual temperature, so the amount of fuel added is increased and white smoke is produced. In this case the sensor will need to be replaced.
If DPF catalytic converter activity has decreased, more fuel will be added without an increase in the exhaust gas temperature, possibly resulting in white smoke.

In this case the front exhaust pipe assembly needs to be replaced. Deterioration of the DPF catalytic converter can cause EGR and injector malfunctions, so if there has not been any repair in the past, check these components as well and repair if necessary.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK TEMPERATURE WHEN WHITE SMOKE IS EMITTED

test1.ptxt: Check whether the white smoke is emitted only when the engine coolant temperature is below 0°C (32°F).

item.ptxt: If so, the smoke is not from the turbocharger and may be the smoke of unburned fuel.
If misfiring occurs, unburned fuel is emitted.

entry.ptxt: White smoke is emitted when the temperature is below 0°C (32°F)
White smoke is emitted regardless of temperature

testgrp.testtitle: INSPECT GLOW PLUG (RESISTANCE)

test1.ptxt: Inspect the glow plug.
Click here

testgrp.testtitle: READ VALUE USING GTS (COMMON RAIL PRESSURE AND TARGET COMMON RAIL PRESSURE)

test1.ptxt: Connect the GTS to the DLC3.
Turn the ignition switch to ON and turn the GTS on.
Start the engine.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Data List / Common Rail Pressure and Target Common Rail Pressure.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Data List

test1.ptxt: Take a snapshot with the GTS.

Measure the difference between the target fuel pressure (Target Common Rail Pressure) and the actual fuel pressure (Common Rail Pressure) when racing the engine with the accelerator pedal fully depressed.

entry.ptxt: Common Rail Pressure is within 5000 kPa of Target Common Rail Pressure

item.ptxt: "Target Common Rail Pressure" is the target fuel pressure controlled by the ECM.
"Common Rail Pressure" is the actual fuel pressure.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK INJECTOR COMPENSATION CODE

test1.ptxt: Read the injector compensation codes.
Click here

specitem.ptxt: Compensation codes stored in the ECM match the compensation codes of the installed injector assemblies.

action.actiontitle: REGISTER INJECTOR COMPENSATION CODE AND PERFORM PILOT QUANTITY LEARNING

item.ptxt: Register the injector compensation codes.
Click here
Perform the injector pilot quantity learning.
Click here

testgrp.testtitle: READ VALUE USING GTS (INJECTION FEEDBACK VAL #1 TO #8 AND INJECTION VOLUME)

test1.ptxt: Check Injection Feedback Val #1 to #8 and Injection Volume in the snapshot taken after the engine is warmed up and idled for 1 minute with the A/C off.

atten4.ptxt: The engine coolant temperature is 75°C (167°F) or higher.

entry.ptxt: Injection Feedback Val #1 to #8 are -3.0 to 3.0 mm3/st or less and Injection Volume is 3.0 to 10 mm3/st

testgrp.testtitle: PERFORM ACTIVE TEST USING GTS (ACTIVATE THE EGR VALVE CLOSE)

test1.ptxt: Connect the GTS to the DLC3.
Start the engine and warm it up, and make sure the A/C switch and all accessory switches are off.
Turn the ignition switch off. Wait for 30 seconds, and then restart the engine.
Turn the GTS on.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Data List / MAF.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Data List

test1.ptxt: Read the MAF value displayed on the GTS while the engine is idling.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Active Test / Activate the EGR Valve Close / Data List / MAF.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Active Test

test1.ptxt: Read the MAF value when the EGR valve is closed using the Active Test function.

item.ptxt: If idling continues for 20 minutes or more, the EGR valve target opening angle becomes 0% (EGR valve fully closed). As this makes diagnosis impossible, it becomes necessary to drive the vehicle or restart the engine.
Before performing the diagnosis, confirm that the EGR valve target opening angle is not 0%.

atten3.ptxt: As the measured values may differ from those shown below due to factors such as differences in measuring environments and changes in vehicle condition due to aging, do not use these values to determine whether the vehicle is malfunctioning or not.

atten4.ptxt: The problem may be a temporary one, due to the entry of deposits or foreign matter. Check that there are no deposits or foreign matter in the electric EGR control valve assembly or mass air flow meter sub-assembly.

item.ptxt: Atmosphere pressure: 101 kPa
Engine coolant temperature: 75°C (167°F)

action.actiontitle: REMOVE DEPOSIT (ELECTRIC EGR CONTROL VALVE ASSEMBLY)

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK ENGINE ASSEMBLY

test1.ptxt: Inspect the engine to see whether white smoke is being emitted due to defects in the engine itself.

test2.ptxt: Check for oil leaking into the combustion chamber due to a faulty valve stem oil seal.
Check for oil leaking into the combustion chamber due to a faulty fuel injector nozzle sheet.

atten4.ptxt: If the engine runs too rough, Injection Feedback Val #1 to #8 cannot be corrected and the readout will (incorrectly) show that Injection Feedback Val #1 to #8 are within the normal range.
If defects are found, perform repairs, and then check that the symptoms are no longer present.

testgrp.testtitle: PERFORM PILOT QUANTITY LEARNING (DETAIL)

test1.ptxt: Perform the pilot quantity learning (detail).
Click here

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK WHEN WHITE SMOKE IS EMITTED

test1.ptxt: Start the engine.
Fully depress the accelerator pedal, and then release it.
Check whether white smoke is emitted or not when racing the engine.

atten3.ptxt: Be sure not to check for white smoke indoors.

testgrp.testtitle: PERFORM ACTIVE TEST USING GTS (CONTROL THE SELECT CYLINDER FUEL CUT)

atten4.ptxt: Use this Active Test to determine the malfunctioning cylinder.

test1.ptxt: Connect the GTS to the DLC3.
Start the engine and turn the GTS on.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Active Test / Control the Select Cylinder Fuel Cut.

atten4.ptxt: If the engine idle speed does not change when an fuel injector is disabled, the cylinder being tested is malfunctioning. Record any malfunctioning cylinders.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Active Test

data-name.name: item-name
data-name.ptxt: Control the Select Cylinder Fuel Cut

app-param-unit.app-param: Control the Select Cylinder Fuel Cut

testgrp.testtitle: PERFORM ACTIVE TEST USING GTS (CHECK THE CYLINDER COMPRESSION)

atten4.ptxt: Use this Active Test to help determine whether a cylinder has compression loss or not.

test1.ptxt: Connect the GTS to the DLC3.
Turn the ignition switch to ON and turn the GTS on.
Enter the following menus: Powertrain / Engine and ECT / Active Test / Check the Cylinder Compression / Data List / Compression / Engine Speed of Cyl #1 to #8.

gts-info.title: Powertrain > Engine and ECT > Active Test

test1.ptxt: Crank the engine.
Check the engine speed during the Active Test.

entry.ptxt: The values of Engine Speed Cyl #1 to #8 are within 10 rpm of each other

atten4.ptxt: When cranking, if the speed of a cylinder is approximately 100 rpm more than the other cylinders, there is probably a complete loss of compression in that cylinder.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK IF FUEL IS BEING SUPPLIED TO FUEL SUPPLY PUMP ASSEMBLY

test1.ptxt: Disconnect the inlet hose from the fuel supply pump assembly.
Operate the priming pump and check that fuel is being supplied to the fuel supply pump assembly.

specitem.ptxt: Fuel is properly supplied to the fuel supply pump assembly when the priming pump is operated.

item.ptxt: A lack of fuel causes the fuel pressure to drop.
Check that the fuel filter element assembly is not clogged.

test1.ptxt: Reconnect the inlet hose.

testgrp.testtitle: CLEAN FUEL FILTER CASE AND REPLACE FUEL FILTER ELEMENT ASSEMBLY

test1.ptxt: Clean the fuel filter case and replace the fuel filter element assembly.

atten4.ptxt: Be sure to clean the inside of the fuel filter case as the injector assemblies may not operate properly if the fuel filter element assembly is installed with foreign matter remaining inside the fuel filter case.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK AND REPLACE CLOGGED FUEL PIPE (INCLUDING FROZEN FUEL) (FUEL TANK - FUEL SUPPLY PUMP ASSEMBLY)

test1.ptxt: Check and replace the clogged fuel pipe.

testgrp.testtitle: BLEED AIR FROM FUEL SYSTEM

atten4.ptxt: If the fuel filter element assembly or fuel pipe has been replaced, be sure to remove any air in the system.

test1.ptxt: Bleed the air from the fuel system.
Click here
Perform PM forced regeneration.
Click here

atten4.ptxt: When fuel lines are disconnected, air may enter the fuel lines, leading to engine starting trouble. Therefore, perform forced regeneration and bleed the air from the fuel lines.

testgrp.testtitle: CONFIRM WHETHER MALFUNCTION HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY REPAIRED

test1.ptxt: Check whether the white smoke problem has been successfully repaired by starting the engine.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK CYLINDER COMPRESSION PRESSURE OF MALFUNCTIONING CYLINDER

atten4.ptxt: Measure the compression of the cylinder that had a high speed during the Active Test "Check the Cylinder Compression".

test1.ptxt: Check cylinder compression pressure.
Click here

action.actiontitle: CHECK ENGINE TO DETERMINE CAUSE OF LOW COMPRESSION

testgrp.testtitle: REPLACE FUEL INJECTOR OF MALFUNCTIONING CYLINDER

atten4.ptxt: It can be determined that the fuel injector is faulty as the corresponding cylinder is malfunctioning, but has no compression loss.

test1.ptxt: Replace the fuel injector of the malfunctioning cylinder.
Click here

item.ptxt: When replacing the fuel injector for a cylinder, always be sure to use a new injection pipe.

Follow the procedure in the repair manual and temporarily install the No. 1 injection pipe sub-assembly, No. 2 injection pipe sub-assembly and No. 1 nozzle leakage pipe assembly, and then correctly position the injector assemblies. After that, tighten parts according to the torque specifications.
If the installation procedure is not performed correctly, injector assemblies may become out of position, which may cause the injector assemblies to deteriorate, resulting in malfunctions.
If an fuel injector deteriorates and malfunctions, other problems such as knocking, rough idle, etc. may occur.
If an fuel injector becomes out of position, it is possible that the seal between the fuel injector and injection pipe sub-assembly may become incomplete, resulting in a fuel leak.

testgrp.testtitle: BLEED AIR FROM FUEL SYSTEM

test1.ptxt: Bleed the air from the fuel system.
Click here
Perform PM forced regeneration.
Click here

atten4.ptxt: When fuel lines are disconnected, air may enter the fuel lines, leading to engine starting trouble. Therefore, perform forced regeneration and bleed the air from the fuel lines.

testgrp.testtitle: REGISTER INJECTOR COMPENSATION CODE AND PERFORM PILOT QUANTITY LEARNING

test1.ptxt: Register the injector compensation codes.
Click here
Perform the injector pilot quantity learning.
Click here

testgrp.testtitle: CONFIRM WHETHER MALFUNCTION HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY REPAIRED

test1.ptxt: Check whether the white smoke problem has been successfully repaired by starting the engine.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK FUEL QUALITY

test1.ptxt: Check that only diesel fuel is being used.
Check that the fuel does not contain any impurities.

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK IDLING CONDITION

test1.ptxt: Start the engine.
Check the idling condition.

entry.ptxt: Engine run smoothly at idle, however white smoke is emitted.
There are problems such as rough idling or engine stall, and white smoke is emitted.

atten4.ptxt: If the pressure in the crank case has risen, white smoke will be produced just after the engine is started. In this case, if blow-by gas is ejected when the oil level gauge is slightly removed*, it is possible that the piston is damaged.

atten3.ptxt: *Do not completely remove the oil level gauge as oil may spray from the opening.

atten4.ptxt: It is possible to determine the faulty cylinder by carrying out the "Check the Cylinder Compression" Active Test.

action.actiontitle: GO TO TURBOCHARGER OIL LEAK AND WHITE SMOKE

testgrp.testtitle: CHECK FOR OIL LEAKAGE

test1.ptxt: Remove any oil in the front exhaust pipe assembly.

atten4.ptxt: Oil in the exhaust pipe is producing white smoke.

test1.ptxt: If there is an oil leak, repair the leak.
